title: How do protons and electrons affect the charge of an atom? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, clearly the excess or deficiency of electrons determines whether the species, the ION, is an ANION, or a CATION respectively. And given any atom, why could it not be an excess or deficiency of positively-charged nuclear particles? Most atoms have an EQUAL number of PROTONS, massive positively-charged nuclear particles, and ELECTRONS, negatively-charged particles of negligible mass that are conceived to whizz about the nuclear core. The sharing of electrons BETWEEN nuclei is responsible for the covalent bond. Mostly, metals are electron-rich species that tend to form positive ions…i.e. [math]M + Δ \rightarrow M^{2+} + 2e^{-}[/math] On the other hand, non-metals, from the right-hand side of the Periodic as we face it, are electron poor materials, they have high nuclear charge, and these TEND to be reduced, i.e. they accept electrons… [math]X+e^{-} \rightarrow X^{-}[/math] Given the identity of the element, i.e. given [math]Z_{\text{the atomic number}}[/math], we can immediately assign the nuclear charge, and thus the electronic charge…

The number of protons determines the amount of positive charge in the nucleus. The number of electrons determines the amount of negative charge surrounding the nucleus; in a neutral atom the numbers of protons and electrons match. If an atom gains one or more electrons, it becomes negatively charged; if it loses one or more, it becomes positive.
